title: Friday, 10th February, 2017

BE11:13am

So, we have China export data to pin this on.

blimey

11:14 am
PM11:14am

PM11:14am

Crazy turn around

BE11:14am

But wasn't that seasonal destocking, or something? I've lost track, due to a slight lack of caring.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Here's Marc Ostwald, who still cares.

BE11:15am

- While the Trade data reinforce the impression of a clear improvement in the underlying trend for exports and imports, predicated on a pick up in manufacturing sector demand globally and improving domestic demand, a trend which has been evident in trade data from Japan, South Korea and Taiwan amongst others in Asia, there are still a number of caveats that have to be applied. Firstly Jan 2016 was especially weak, coinciding as it did with the trough in global commodity prices, and nominal USD values for exports and imports were actually lower than those seen in January 2014 and January 2015. Secondly January/February trade data always have to be treated with great care given Lunar New Year effects, which in this case may have seen some front loading of exports and imports, and in all likelihood the February data will show a sharp slowing relative to this month's reading. Last but not least export and import values are clearly being boosted by the rise in energy and commodity prices, and indeed the fall in the CNY. Eminently none of this serves to alter concerns that Trump's rhetoric suggests considerable headwinds for Chinese exports to the US going forward.

Trade surplus with the US was 21.37bn

So, Just Eat mentioned.

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 520.50, down 34 (-6.13%), High: 525.50, Low: 512.00, Volume: 4.67m

PM11:17am

http://www.investe...1702100700085507W/

Urgent family matters can be very sudden. And the privacty of them is best respected.

11:17 am
PM11:18am

David Buttress off

PM11:18am

Can't ignore the resultant boardroom turmoil tho

PM11:18am

Didn't the FD go early as well?

11:18 am
BE11:19am

It is rather looking rather light in he C suite, yes. Chairman becomes an executive and the CEO search begins.

BE11:19am

Gist from the followers is, "big loss".

BE11:19am

Goldman .....

11:19 am
BE11:19am

We expect the uncertainty created by the departure of David Buttress to be taken negatively, and may be a cause for concern among investors, given his strong track record in starting the UK business, growing the overall company, and evolving JUST EAT’s strategy into a platform for both consumers and restaurants, offering multiple revenue levers over the mid to long-term. We do not expect Mr. Hughes or an eventual new CEO to change the company’s strategy, which may calm investor concerns.

BE11:20am

.... which is shop, of course.

BE11:20am

JUST EAT is due to report FY16 results on March 1 and is a CL-Buy (last close 555p). Our 12-month price target of 870p is based 85% on our SOTP valuation and 15% on an M&A valuation (45x 2017E EV/EBITDA, in line with historical sector transactions). Key risks include disruptive competitor actions, market share losses, execution, lower-than-expected penetration of internet ordering, shift in consumer preferences away from takeaways.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

And UBS. Not shop, but sellers.

BE11:21am

Buttress launched Just Eat's UK business in March 2006 and has been instrumental in driving the company forward, becoming Group CEO in 2013. Many investors we speak to regard him as a key asset in the company so we think this is likely to be taken negatively by the market. Additionally, Just Eat is in the process of buying UK rival hungryhouse and in the process of integrating SkipTheDishes in Canada, so understandably a mgt change is unwelcome. Having said that, Chairman Hughes has been a Director since 2011, and will assume the CEO role until a replacement is found. Furthermore, Buttress has committed to serving as a non-executive director for at least one year from the end of March. Chairman Hughes said "The company is very strongly positioned for the future."

BE11:21am

Notes also the you pay 25% less for Grubhub .....

11:21 am
BE11:21am

.... or did at the start of the day.

BE11:22am

Grubhub (not covered) reported numbers on Wednesday. Its new guidance for 2017 calls for 26-34% growth and 25-31% EBITDA margins vs consensus for Just Eat at 31% growth and a 32% EBITDA margin. The mid-point of Grubhub's 2017 sales guidance puts it at 4.7x 2017 EV/Sales vs Just Eat at 7.4x (cons.) [36% discount]. The mid-point of its 2017 EBITDA guidance puts it at 17.1x 2017 EV/EBITDA vs Just Eat at 22.8x (cons.) [25% discount]. It trades at 1x 2016 GMVthey vs Just Eat at 1.5x (2016E) [33% discount]. Investors we have spoken to say part of the reason for Just Eat's premium is its superior management team.

BE11:23am

Just Eat numbers are 7th March, incidentally. Not seem much grumbling yet about whether it's too hot or too cold to order a pizza, but I guess that's a spring and autumn factor.

11:23 am
PM11:23am

Tricky for the bears to jump on this news

PM11:23am

Not knowing why Buttress is off

PM11:23am

here's a couple of pars from Campling -- Northern Trust

11:23 am
PM11:23am

We feel these changes couldn't come at a more challenging time for the company. At the last set of results the KPI ‘UK order growth’ showed that 4Q16 UK order growth slowed to just 24%. Now that compares to UK order growth at the start of the year in F1Q of 40% YoY. The same we see as a significant deceleration of growth at a time competition has intensified and is the first quarter in which Uber and Amazon has entered the market.

We expect challenges to Just Eat’s planned path to maintaining high growth while pushing through higher commission rates, and their need to defend mind and market share as UK competition intensifies will likely pressure EBITDA margins. In contrast the street expects increased margins, rising from 30% in FY16 to 32.6% in FY17 (Source: Bloomberg). Add in the fact the key drivers of the business are now leaving or recently departed and add in the outlook of slowing growth and margin risk we find the valuation of F12M 35x P/E and 8.3x P/Sales too rich to stomach. We remain sellers of JE/ LN.

PM11:30am

11:30 am

PM11:31am

BE11:31am

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Want some sellside? Barclays is neutral on RBMJ so will do for a balanced view.

BE11:34am

Reckitt has confirmed it is to acquire Mead for $90 per share in cash. The target for cost savings (7% of Mead sales) is towards the low end of our base case, whilst the growth outlook for Mead (upper end 3-5% category growth range) seems somewhat unambitious. On this basis the returns (ROIC greater than WACC year 5) seem hard to justify. There is scope for revenue synergies in time to bring to the equation of course. Although we have argued that Mead may seem a ‘second best’ deal to more plain vanilla consumer health there are clear strategic merits (global roll out of Mead brands through RB’s health distribution channels with RB adding traditional FMCG innovation and marketing capability to the category).

BE11:34am

Meanwhile, Q4/ FY16 results have been brought forward, the highlight being a softer than expected end to the year for top line growth and a subdued outlook to FY 17. We remain EW on Reckitt with trading on both the base business and Mead currently difficult and we await more clarity on RB’s plans for Mead.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

As in ..........

BE11:34am

The strategic arguments put forward by the company look sensible enough and consistent with some of our thoughts from our recently published note. Mead is expected to enhance RB’s presence in EMs, with China becoming its second largest market. RB will bring consumer centric innovation and ability to scale global brands to Mead. RB hopes to grow Mead at the upper end of an estimated category growth rate of 3-5%. This compares with our long term RB stand alone forecast of +4.4%, slightly lower than our initial thoughts of a c.6% growth rate, although clearly revenue synergies here will be a key variable.

· We expect the likelihood of third party intervention as low

BE11:35am

Oh, and note the FY17 warning.

11:36 am

BE11:37am

Here's Morgan Stanley on Reckitt Johnson, just for completeness.

BE11:37am

.... actually, not Morgan Stanley. As it's Mead's advisor, so can't say anything of interest.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

RBC's unattached. Let's try them.

BE11:38am

RB has announced both the acquisition of Mead Johnson for $90 per share and its full year results (with outlook for 2017’s revenue growth of 3% below the company compiled consensus of 4.2%). The only meaningful difference from our initial expectation of the acquisition (‘RB: downgrading to Underperform’) is that RB envisages
£200m of synergies (c.7% of forecast Mead Johnson sales) whereas we had anticipated £150m. The deal is double digit EPS accretive (no surprise) and ROIC to exceed WACC in five years ... this feels like a big ask to us. It is expected to complete by the end of Q3 2017.
FY16 EPS of 302p were 2% ahead of consensus on the back of £2,777m operating profit (0.5% ahead of consensus). Like-for-like revenue growth for the quarter came in at 1%, missing consensus by 70bps, with the company flagging weakness in North America and Russia; ENA like-for-like growth was -2% or 280bps below consensus.
Importantly, the company is flagging that it expects ‘macro conditions to remain challenging and for a number of existing headwinds to persist in the first half’. On the back of this, Reckitt expects Like-for-like growth of 3% in FY17 (Cons. is for 4.2%), continuing the uninspiring trend the company has been experiencing.
Our cautious view is predicated on the acquisition of Mead Johnson being a less than compelling deal strategically, operationally and financially. This hasn’t changed.
Given the subdued sales outlook for 2017’s sales growth we reiterate our Underperform recommendation.

BE11:39am

Kinda baffled why Reckitt shares have held flat throughout this.

BE11:44am

In terms of sellside ....... BAT getting a push from Berenberg.

11:44 am

With its acquisition of Reynolds American, BAT will be the undisputed world leader in the vaping market.....

BE11:44am

BE11:45am

BE11:46am

Berenberg's keeping a closer eye on it all, though. Which is nice of them.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

BAT is now very well positioned to take advantage of the potential growth of the Next Generation Products (NGPs). When combined with Reynolds American, BAT has, through a mixture of acquisitions and its own investments, become market leader in vaping in the US, UK and Poland but also with a presence in most key western European markets. In December 2016 the group launched its heated tobacco product in the city of Sendai in Japan, and it has a hybrid called iFUSE in the Romanian market. On the vaping side BAT has a portfolio of open and closed system products, the ability to develop and produce
its own e-liquids and more recently developed a new convenient format called epebble. Furthermore, in 2017 it will be looking to launch a vaping product called ‘Raptor’ that is said to allow a more rapid nicotine absorption by consumers than historical products. 2017 is likely to be the year that PMI’s iQOS makes significant volume gains but it is clear that BAT has a very competitive portfolio across all existing products, though how successful or otherwise will not become clear until 2018. It is worth pointing out that BAT will be able to market its full range of products in the important US market, where the tobacco market leader, Altria Group, has only made selective investments in vaping and will be the license holder for iQOS when this is launched post-approval by the FDA, probably in 2018.

"epebble"

BE11:46am

"Raptor"

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Luckily, Berenberg's stuff isn't all about epebbles and iFuses.

BE11:49am

Following the consolidation of Reynolds American the group will generate over 40% of its net profits from the US market and c63% of profits from the developed world. Historically, BAT had a strong bias towards the emerging markets (EM) but this has now changed. We believe this points to both how attractive management views the US market following the 2015 acquisition of Lorillard by Reynolds American, but also possibly that some of the major challenges of volume declines and offsetting rising costs will be felt primarily in the EM.

BE11:50am

BAT stated it estimates potential cost synergies of around $400m but without mentioning a timeframe. Based on 2016 estimates this would represent 2.2% of the combined cost base, excluding Medicaid Settlement (MSA) and FDA payments. Given the lack of geographic overlap the low rate of cost savings is hardly surprising; moreover the savings would represent an impressive 11% of the estimated 2016 cost base (excluding MSA and FDA payments) of Reynolds American as a standalone business. Clearly BAT could be a major beneficiary of any moves to reduce the US corporate tax rate, but our current estimates assume no change.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

We increase our price target by 10% to 5,670p and upgrade the rating from Hold to Buy. The price target reflects the change in the DCF valuation based on the estimates for the combined group.

http://www.cancerr...n=owntwitter_tweet

BE11:55am

In part for reasons @wayneJ just outlined: branding is quite important here, and any move to de-brand and cut advertising -- as we've seen with actual proper tobacco -- could be disruptive.

BE11:55am

11:59 am

An absolute grind. I'm slightly tempted to pick up on that mention on the right of Elementis's acquisition.

PM11:59am

(Flaneur -- this has been happening down south for a good while. Believe there were planning changes to encourage it.)

BE11:59am

Buying SummitReheis for $360m

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

The global leader in antiperspirant, no less!

PM12:00pm

Really?

PM12:00pm

Assume this would be the likes of Unilever

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

This is the ingredients end of things. De-sweatifying stuff accounts for 60% of sales

BE12:01pm

Here comes Credit Suisse to explain.

BE12:01pm

Elementis have announced the acquisition of SummitReheis, a manufacturer of inputs into personal care products (60% anti-perspirants) for an enterprise value of $360mn (represents 12.9x EBITDA pre-synergies, CS estimates 10.7x post synergies). Additionally, Elementis confirmed FY16 earnings to be in line with market expectations and highlighted the acquisition will not impact the special dividend consideration for 2016. SummitReheis is a private company, we make no earnings changes at this stage pending further analysis

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

■ Financially: We estimate the transaction is 14% eps accretive (on FY17F), pre synergie and 18% accretive post synergies. Post-acquisition leverage increases to a comfortable ~1.6x (ND/EBITDA), Elementis have raised $475mn new debt.

■ Operationally, post-acquisition personal care revenues will increase to ~25% of group. Cost synergies are targeted at $3mn, or ~2% of SummitReheis revenues (lower end of chemical transactions). We estimate further revenue synergies of $3mn based on 9% additional revenue opportunities from cross-selling products.

■ Strategically: We believe this transaction further diversifies Elementis' portfolio and builds on the company strengths in Personal Care. Increasing their position in this market should assist in leveraging their current product portfolio based around their unique access the hectorite clay.

BE12:02pm

...... which answers my "what's antiperspirant made out of?" question. Hectorite clay. There we are.

BE12:03pm

N+1 Singer as well.

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

You know I learn stuff every day from you Bryce

PM12:03pm

Every single day

PM12:03pm

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hectorite

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

At least 70% of it should be checked with a second source, to be fair. Wikipedia will do for the moment.

BE12:04pm

Singer incoming.

BE12:04pm

This materially enhances the Group’s offering in personal care (now 30% of Group operating profit on a pro-forma basis) and prompts double digit earnings upgrades to FY18, the first full year post acquisition. The acquisition will enhance the EBITDA margin as well as earnings, reflecting the high quality of the business acquired. The multiple looks undemanding at 11.8x FY16 EV/EBITDA for a specialties business that adds scale to one of Elementis’ most attractive niches. It is an acquisition on a much larger scale than recent bolt-ons, confirmation of the Group’s growth ambitions under the new management team. Underlying trading is said to be in line and the special dividend will be paid for FY16, as expected. We upgrade our forecasts for the acquisition here. Our first take is an EPS upgrade of 7% to FY17 assuming a half year contribution and c.15% to FY18. The special dividend drops out mechanistically from FY17. Elementis remains one of our Best Ideas for 2017.

12:04 pm

FT Alphaville says "this isn't a typical Reckitt target.... which invites all sorts of questions about why management is so keen to bulk up" Notes possible speculation "whether Reckitt could plausibly be a target for someone else -- which seems unlikely but you never know -- so is looking for a poison pill." Adds that "I've no opinion on such speculation, should it ever arise, which it might have already, though not from me."
